Dear Ms. Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth H allegedly “cheeked” medications, hid them in her room
and ingested them at once on 9/18/23.
Investigation I interviewed Complainant, also Foster Care Supervisor, via
phone. She said she read documents from Vista Maria that raised
concerns about how Youth H gets access to medication. Prior to
reporting these allegations, Complainant said she and Youth H’s
foster care worker have been involved in Vista Maria treatment
planning meetings and have “followed through with all of the tasks
Vista Maria requested.” Complainant said her second-line
supervisor told her to report these allegations.
I notified Youth H’s Foster Care Worker of the investigation
assignment. She expressed no additional concerns.
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
An incident report on 9/1/23 at 7:30pm indicated Youth H informed
Staff 3 that she swallowed a “fidget.” Thirty minutes later she told
the same staff she ingested some pills that she had stashed in her
bra. No one saw Youth H swallow anything. However, based on
her self-report, she was transported to Garden City Hospital.
According to the hospital report, Youth H then told medical
professionals she did not ingest any pills. Lab test results were
negative for an overdose and abdomen x-rays showed no foreign
body (fidget) present. Youth H remained hospitalized for nearly
two weeks for suicidal ideation and then discharged back to Vista
Maria on 9/13/23.
On 9/17/23 Youth H grabbed a first aid kit in a vehicle and
swallowed two over-the-counter aspirin. Details of this incident is
found in the next allegation below.
On 9/18/23 at 9:00am, an incident report by Therapist indicated
“Youth H quickly grabbed something from the side of her bed and
2

placed it in her mouth and began drinking apple juice. Staff 3
quickly grabbed the apple juice and told Youth H to spit out what
she had in her mouth.” Youth H told the staff she already
swallowed it.” Staff 3 asked Youth H what she swallowed and
where she got it. Youth H told her it was a pill but refused to say
how she got it.
At 10:00 am on 9/18/23 an incident report indicated Youth H told
Nurse 1 she swallowed a pill, but also refused to tell Nurse
how/where she got it. Youth H was not taken to the hospital on
that occasion.
I interviewed Nurse 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. She
indicated Youth H is diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress
Disorder, Major Depressive Disorder and Rule Out Borderline
Personality Disorder. Nurse 2 noted Youth H has been
transported to the emergency room twelve times since she was
admitted to Vista Maria in April 2023. The emergency room visits
were all for self-reported attempts to harm herself ranging from
claims to having ingested unknown pills and foreign objects to
inserting objects into her vagina.
Nurse 2 said Youth H is prescribed a total of 14 pills per day. To
reduce the risk of her hiding pills in her mouth, I asked Nurse 2 if
her pills can be crushed prior to dispensing. Nurse 2 affirmed that
some of them can, and others cannot. She agreed to consult with
the youth’s psychiatrist.
I interviewed Therapist jointly with Government Worker 1. As
indicated in the incident report, while in Youth H’s room, she said
she saw her grab “something” and put it in her mouth. Youth H
told Therapist it was a pill but refused to provide additional
information.
I interviewed Team Leader jointly with Government Worker 1.
She said Youth H told her she “cheeked” and later ingested her
own medication, but Team Leader has never seen her do it. Most,
if not all, of her attempts to harm herself are by her own self-report
and not witnessed by staff. Team Leader also said that whenever
Youth H’s room has been searched and cleared, no harmful items
have been found.
I interviewed Youth H jointly with Government Worker. She
understood the meaning of the “cheeking” medication and
explained “It’s when you hide pills in your mouth to take a bunch
later.” A couple weeks ago, Youth H claimed she “cheeked” a
3

total of five pills on three separate occasions because she wanted
to die. She said Supervisors usually have her open her mouth to
make sure she swallowed her pills. She did not remember what
Supervisor passed her medication the time(s) she hid them in her
mouth.
Youth H said she stored the five pills on the floor between her bed
and the wall and swallowed them when staff were not present.
She said no staff person saw the pills or saw her swallow them.
Ten minutes after ingesting them, Youth H said she told Team
Leader what she did. “They sent me to the hospital emergency
room for two weeks then sent me back.”
I interviewed Supervisor who has worked at the facility for nine
years. She said she passes medication to Youth H and has never
caught her “cheeking.” “I asked her to open her mouth and cough.
I look in her mouth and make sure she drinks a full cup of
water…It’s still possible to “cheek” them though.” To her
knowledge, Supervisor said all staff follow this procedure.
I interviewed Team Leader who has worked at the facility for over
four years. She said she passes medication to Youth H and has
never caught her “cheeking.” “I tell them to open their mouth,
cough and drink plenty of water.”
I reviewed the facility’s medication policy. The policy states that
supervisors passing medication should: “Carefully watch the client
take medication and verify all pills have been swallowed by
checking the mouth for any retained medication.” The way this is
verified is by having the youth open her mouth to show she
swallowed the pills.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis While Youth H clearly knows how to “cheek” medication, at this
point there is no evidence she hid pills in her mouth and ingested
them later. No staff at Vista Maria ever actually saw the pills she
claimed to have hidden and ingested. After Youth H claimed to
have ingested extra pills on 9/1/23, a lab test showed no evidence
of an overdose or higher than expected levels of drugs in her
system. The referral source and treatment team at Vista Maria
will continue collaborating strategies to keep Youth H safe.
CONSULTATION
Having youths open their mouths guards against “cheeking” but
does not fully prevent it. The only way to assure Youth H does not
4

hide pills in her mouth would be to discontinue all of her
medications. Another way to lower the risk would be to crush her
prescribed pills before dispensing them. These are decisions that
can only be by made by her treating psychiatrist. Otherwise, the
clinical treatment team should continue brainstorming strategies to
protect Youth H from possessing pills and other items that can be
ingested or inserted.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (2) Resident medications shall be kept in the original pharmacy
Description supplied container until dispensed, shall be kept with the
equipment to administer it in a locked area, and refrigerated, if
required.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth H allegedly took unknown medication from a first aid kit in a
facility vehicle and ingested it.
Investigation On 9/17/23 Youth H said she was in the van with Staff 1 and 2
and refused to exit the vehicle. Staff 1 and 2 exited the vehicle
and went on either side of it to encourage her out of the van.
Youth H said she locked the doors with the staff outside, jumped
into the front seat, opened a first aid kit, removed a packet of over-
the-counter pain reliever (two pills), and swallowed them before
the staff could unlock the door. Again, Youth H said she took the
two pills because she wanted to die.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
worked at the facility for one year. Upon returning to Youth H to
Vista Maria from another hospital run on 9/17/23, Staff 1 said she
and Staff 2 asked Youth H to exit the vehicle. Youth H laid in the
back seat refusing to exit. Staff 1 and 2 stepped out of the vehicle
to the back doors. Youth H jumped over the seats to the front,
grabbed a first aid kit from the driver’s side door pocket, and
swallowed a small packet of non-aspirin pills. After that, Youth H
willingly walked to the residential building. Staff notified the facility
nurse and Youth H was not returned to the hospital.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
worked at the facility for one month. She said she, Staff 1 and
Youth H returned back to Vista Maria from the hospital. Staff 1
was in the passenger seat and Youth H was in the backseat
5

alone. After parking, Youth H refused to exit the van. “Staff 1
opened the door to the backseat. I saw Youth H hop up to the
front and grab a first aid kit from somewhere. I didn’t know there
was a first aid kit in the van. I heard Staff 1 tell Youth H not to
take pills. I did not see her swallow any pills. Youth H walked to
the building after that on her own…The nurse or supervisor said it
was aspirin she took.”
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis Youth H accessed over-the-counter pain reliever from a first aid kit
she found in a Vista Maria vehicle. The licensing rule indicates all
medication should be kept in a locked area.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a corrective action plan is required.
